prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The person is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their sister's boyfriend he's not family.

First, the situation: The sister has been dating this guy for under three months. The author has issues with the guy because he made dangerous choices—like driving drunk with the sister in the car and hanging out with an ex-felon to buy drugs. The author thinks the guy is a bad influence but hasn't said much before. Now, the boyfriend is being overly familiar, calling the author "brother" and "fam," showing up uninvited, and attaching himself when they're at their mom's house. The author then tells him he's not family, just the guy the sister is dating now. The sister hasn't talked to the author since, and they're wondering if they were wrong.

So, the key points are the author's intentions and the actions. The author's main concern is protecting their sister from someone they see as a danger. They've kept their opinions to themselves until now but felt the need to set a boundary when the boyfriend started acting too familiar. The author might have overstepped by being direct and maybe harsh, but is that in the wrong? On one hand, the boyfriend's actions are concerning, and the author is within their right to express concern. On the other hand, the author didn't consult the sister first, which could have caused the rift. But the author did mention that they respect her choice to date him, just want to set boundaries. 

The boyfriend's behavior of trying to be close with the family is common, but the author might have felt it was overstepping. Telling him he's not family could be seen as necessary for setting boundaries, especially given the risks. However, the way it was said might have been abrupt. But given the circumstances, maybe the author isn't wrong. The answer might be B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because they're trying to protect their sister and set boundaries, even if it caused tension.
